message.content: Yes, the authors specify all the training details in their experiments. In both the synthetic problems and real-world dataset sections, they provide details on the initial quadrature hyperparameters, proposal distribution partition ratio, prior settings, likelihood functions, metrics used for evaluation, and optimization. In the Appendix 6 section, they present more details related to the specific settings and parameters of each problem, including the bounds for RMSE evaluation in the real-world applications. This level of detail allows for a comprehensive understanding of the methods and the reproducibility of the experiments.

Yes, the authors specify all the training details in the experiments section and the appendix 6 section of the paper. They provide information about the synthetic and real-world datasets used, the prior and likelihood functions, the training dataset generation, problem settings, hyperparameters, metrics for evaluation, and boundaries for grid samples in the logarithmic space. Overall, the experimental setup and training details are documented thoroughly.

Yes, the authors provide detailed information about the training process in their experiments. They specify the synthetic problems, real-world datasets, metrics used, model implementations, and hyperparameters involved in the experiments. They also discuss the results and offer additional experiments in the appendix. This detailed information allows for a clearer understanding of how the experiments were conducted and the decisions made regarding the training process.
